questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with proptosis. The mass responsible for same was biopsied and found to be a desmin positive tumor. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/332

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of lung
Squamous cell carcinoma of lung
Large cell carcinoma of lung

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with generalized tiredness, malaise, muscle weakness, and bone pain. Laboratory investigations reveal serum calcium to be 13 mg/dL. Which of the following  lung cancers is implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

Option C:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia, often due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP), which leads to increased calcium reabsorption and bone resorption.

Explanation:

Option A. Small cell carcinoma of the lung: Small cell carcinoma of the lung is more commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like SIADH or Cushing's syndrome due to ectopic ACTH production, rather than hypercalcemia.

Option B. Adenosquamous carcinoma of the lung: Adenosquamous carcinoma of the lung can produce paraneoplastic syndromes, but it is not the most common type associated with hypercalcemia.

Option D. Large cell carcinoma of the lung: Large cell carcinoma can present with several paraneoplastic syndromes, but it is not the most frequent cause of paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.

Educational Objective:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is frequently associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia, often due to the secretion of PTHrP, leading to elevated calcium levels that manifest with symptoms such as fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 329

choices.text: Associated with asbestos exposure
Histology shows biphasic pattern
Occurs in late middle age

questions.text: All are true regarding mesothelioma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bilaterally symmetrical

 

  • Mesothelioma is an asbestos exposure related tumor having Mean age of presentation as 50-70 years. Micro­scopically it may have both epithelioid and sarcomatoid patterns (biphasic pattern).

 

Option A:

 

Bilaterally symmetrical is not typically characteristic of mesothelioma. Pleural mesotheliomas are more often right-sided, possibly due to the greater volume of the right pleural cavity, and while bilateral disease can occur, it is usually unilateral at presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Associated with asbestos exposure is correct. Mesothelioma has a well-established association with asbestos exposure, often presenting decades after initial exposure.

 

Option C: Histology shows a biphasic pattern is true for mesothelioma. Microscopically, it can exhibit both epithelioid and sarcomatoid features, hence referred to as biphasic.

 

Option D: Occurs in late middle age is also true. Mesothelioma typically presents in the mean age group of 50 to 70 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is typically unilateral at presentation, not bilaterally symmetrical, and is associated with asbestos exposure, often presenting in late middle age with a histological biphasic pattern.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 735)

questions.text: A 67-year male with history of chronic smoking hemoptysis with cough. Bronchoscopic biopsy from centrally located mass shows undifferentiated tumor histopathologically. Most useful I.H.C. (immunohistochemical) marker to make a proper diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cytokeratin

Option A:

  • The presence of chronic smoking, cough and hemoptysis in old man is a pointer towards a diagnosis of bronchogenic cancer. The central location suggests the possibility of a squamous cell cancer.
  • Robbins writes “Histologically, this tumor is char­acterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges”.

Explanation:

Option C: HMB is a marker of melanoma,

Option D: Hep par1 is a marker of liver cancer

Option B: TTF 1 is a marker of adenocarcinoma of the lung

Educational Objective:

The appropriate immunohistochemical marker for diagnosis of a centrally located bronchogenic carcinoma in a patient with a history of chronic smoking, is cytokeratin.

 

(Robbins 10th/ 720)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic lung disease presents with progressive dyspnea. Imaging reveals the presence of scar tissue in the lung parenchyma, likely a consequence of chronic inflammation and injury. Which of the following types of lung cancer is most commonly associated with chronic lung scarring and inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenocarcinoma

Option A:

Adenocarcinoma of the lung often arises in the periphery of the lung and can be associated with areas of scarring, known as scar carcinomas. This scarring may result from chronic inflammation and is commonly seen in this lung cancer subtype.

Explanation:

Option B: Oat cell carcinoma, also known as small cell lung cancer, is strongly associated with smoking and typically arises in the central regions of the lungs. It is less likely to be associated with lung scarring compared to adenocarcinoma.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung often arises in the central part of the lungs and is linked to smoking. It may be related to chronic inflammation but is not typically associated with lung scarring as adenocarcinoma is.

Option D: Large cell cancer of the lung can appear in any part of the lung and tends to grow rapidly. Like squamous cell carcinoma, it is not primarily associated with pre-existing lung scarring.

Educational Objective:

Adenocarcinoma is the type of lung cancer most commonly associated with chronic lung scarring and inflammation, presenting as peripheral lung tumors that may arise from areas of scar tissue.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 716)

choices.text: Pathology is peripheral in location
More common in females
Azzopardi effect is seen
Cells are p63 and p40 positive

questions.text: A 70-year male, chronic smoker develops a non productive chronic cough since past 6 months. He also has weight loss, anorexia and chest pain. CT scan shows a mass lesion from which biopsy is taken (image given along side). Which of the statements best describes the above pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cells are p63 and p40 positive    

Option D:

Cells are p63 and p40 positive – This statement is correct for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. These immunohistochemical markers are commonly used to support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

Explanation:

Option A: Pathology is peripheral in location – This would typically describe adenocarcinoma of the lung, not squamous cell carcinoma which commonly presents as a central lesion, especially in smokers.

Option B: More common in females – Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung has been historically more common in males, particularly those with a history of smoking.

Option C: Azzopardi effect is seen – This is characteristic of small cell carcinoma of the lung, where necrotic cells impart a basophilic staining to blood vessel walls, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Educational Objective:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly central in location, more prevalent in male smokers, and is characterized by cells that are p63 and p40 positive on immunohistochemical staining.

questions.text: A 56 year male smoker complains of weight loss, anorexia, chest pain and listlessness since 8 months. The following findings are noted in bronchioalveolar lavage fluid. Which of the following is LEAST LIKELY to be present with this pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypercalcemia

Option C:

Hypercalcemia is often associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung due to ectopic parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) production, not typically with small cell lung cancer.

Explanation:

Option A: Hyponatremia may be seen due to inappropriate ADH secretion by small cell carcinoma of the lung, which is known for paraneoplastic syndromes, including SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone).

Option B: Gynecomastia can result from ectopic gonadotropin production, which can occur with certain lung carcinomas such as small cell lung cancer.

Option D: Cushing's syndrome can be a manifestation of ectopic ACTH production by small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Educational Objective:

Hypercalcemia is typically associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung and is the least likely paraneoplastic syndrome to be associated with small cell lung cancer, which is more commonly related to ectopic production of ADH, ACTH, or gonadotropins.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman had complaints of enophthalmos, meiosis, anhidrosis and ptosis. X ray chest shows right upper lobe opacification with destruction of rib. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bronchogenic carcinoma

Option C:

This patient has features of Horner syndrome due to involvement of sympathetic ganglia by bronchogenic carcinoma.

These tumors are at upper lobe (apex) of lung and are known as Pancoast tumour. 

Bronchogenic carcinoma, specifically a Pancoast tumor located at the apex of the lung, can present with Horner's syndrome due to invasion of the cervical sympathetic chain and may cause rib destruction due to local invasion.

Explanation:

Option A: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that primarily causes bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement, but it typically does not present with Horner's syndrome or rib destruction.

Option B: Tuberculosis can cause upper lobe opacities and cavitation, especially reactivation tuberculosis, but it is less likely to cause Horner's syndrome and rib destruction unless there is direct extension of the infection, which is rare.

Option D: Lobar pneumonia is an acute infectious process that affects a large and continuous area of the lobe of a lung. It generally presents with consolidation on imaging but does not cause Horner's syndrome or rib destruction.

Educational Objective:

Pancoast tumor is when a patient presents with symptoms of Horner's syndrome and imaging shows a lung lesion at the apex with associated bone destruction, which is not characteristic features of sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, or lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom seen in patients with lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cough

Option A:

The major presenting complaints of lung cancer patients are cough (most common followed by weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea.

Cough is the most frequent initial symptom of lung cancer due to irritation or obstruction of the airways and can be either productive or non-productive.

Explanation:

Option B: Dyspnea or shortness of breath is a common symptom but typically occurs later as the tumor grows or if there is involvement of the lung parenchyma, pleura, or lymphatic spread causing obstruction.

Option C: Weight loss is often a sign of systemic illness and can be present in lung cancer patients, especially as the disease progresses, due to cancer cachexia or tumor metabolism effects.

Option D: Chest pain may occur, particularly if the tumor invades the pleura or chest wall, but it is less common as an initial symptom compared to cough.

Educational Objective:

Cough is the most common presenting symptom in patients with lung cancer, which can be due to airway irritation or obstruction by the tumor.

 

Robbins 10th/ 721

choices.text: Superior vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A 66-year-old male with a clinical history of systemic hypertension and emphysema is brought to the emergency. He is a smoker for past 20 years. The physician examining him notices marked congestion of his head, neck, and upper extremities. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior vena cava syndrome

Option D:

Superior vena cava syndrome occurs due to obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to congestion of the head, neck, and upper extremities, which matches the patient's presentation. It can be caused by a lung tumor or other intrathoracic mass compressing the superior vena cava.

Explanation:

Option A: Horner's syndrome is characterized by ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, and enophthalmos due to disruption of the sympathetic nervous pathway, often without vascular congestion as described.

Option B: Aortic dissection may present with severe chest pain and can be catastrophic, but it would not typically cause congestion of the head, neck, and upper extremities.

Option C: Spontaneous pneumothorax presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea. It is related to the collapse of a lung but would not cause upper body congestion.

Educational Objective:

The clinical presentation of superior vena cava syndrome, includes congestion of the head, neck, and upper extremities due to obstruction of venous return by a tumor or other mass.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents with chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Imaging reveals a centrally located lung mass with evidence of cavity formation. Biopsy of the lesion confirms the diagnosis of bronchogenic carcinoma. Which type of bronchogenic carcinoma is most commonly associated with the observed cavity formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Squamous cell

Option A:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is known for central necrosis leading to cavitation within the tumor mass. It is more commonly associated with smokers and is often located centrally in the lungs.

Explanation:

Option B: Oat cell carcinoma, or small cell lung cancer, is highly aggressive and associated with smoking. However, it typically does not lead to cavitary lesions; instead, it is known for rapid growth and early metastasis.

Option C: Adenocarcinoma of the lung generally presents as peripheral lesions and is less likely than squamous cell carcinoma to present with cavitation.

Option D: Bronchoalveolar carcinoma, a subtype of adenocarcinoma, typically presents with a pneumonia-like consolidation rather than cavitation and is less related to smoking compared to other types.

Educational Objective:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 716)

choices.text: History of prior treatment of TB is a usual finding
Can show both epitheloid and sarcomatous elements on histology

questions.text: A 58 year male factory worker complains of dyspnea along with chest pain and tiredness since 2 years. He also had a right sided pleural effusion which was drained. Patient died after 6 months. The appearance of his lung at autopsy is given in the image. Which statement regarding the pathology is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Can show both epitheloid and sarcomatous elements on histology

Option B:

The pathology shown here is of a malignant mesothelioma arising from pleura wherein the entire lung is encased in a thick greyish- white pleural tumour. Other features include

 

  • 20% of tumours show both epithelioid and sarcomatoid elements on histology. 
  • Deletion of  chromosome 9p is common.
  • There is NO increased risk of developing mesothelioma in pts’ of TB. 
  • It occurs mainly due to prolonged exposure with asbestos (shipping industry).
  • Mesothelioma DOESNOT elaborate ectopic hormones.

Educational Objective:

Malignant mesothelioma can histologically exhibit both epithelioid and sarcomatoid elements, which is a notable feature in approximately 20% of tumors, emphasizing the disease's diverse histological presentation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 695)
